subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Excellent! We really wanted the feedback from someone from the southern hemisphere. ... This issue is actually coming up in the news and deserves its own
messageBody:
myzomela63 wrote:
>
>
>
> Anthony,
>
> Here's an Australian reviewing your Australian chart. I'll give it
> 99%!

Excellent! We really wanted the feedback from someone from the southern
hemisphere.

>
> I would certainly distinguish between #33AWE and #34Ox and between
> #29EIGHt and #30At. Yes, although the IPA differs from the BBC
> chart, the assignment of lexical sets is much the same. So when I
> picked up the QS manual a few weeks ago, there were few letters that
> bothered me. Use of #29EIGHt-#25Roe for the SQUARE set was the main
> one. Your proposal of #28Et-#25Roe is spot-on.

This issue is actually coming up in the news and deserves its own
thread, but I mind as well bring it up here. If we use #28 Et-#25 Roe
for Square, what do we use for words like "merry?" (I see there is no
lexical set for this word. Does it belong to Nurse? I certainly don't
pronounce it that way.)

Or, we can put it this way. What letters do we use for Mary the name;
Marry, as in marriage; and merry?


>
> And one warning. Some Australians may want to keep terminal
> unstressed "Eat" written as #27Eat, rather than #26It. (At least one
> does,
> http://members.optusnet.com.au/~malt99/project_quickscript_website/ind
> <http://members.optusnet.com.au/~malt99/project_quickscript_website/ind>
> ex.html. But some of those spellings are quite idiosyncratic and
> would, I think, make Australian QS too difficult to read elsewhere.)
> Keep your footnote as it is.

I think most Americans and British would want to use #27 EAT.

>
> And since this thread is supposed to be about the QS news, I'll add
> my thanks to Paul. Since I'm new to QS, I'm still reading quite
> slowly, and the American spellings sometimes make me blink, then
> smile. Particularly cases where #3Tea is dropped. But that in no
> way diminshes the value of QS news: it's all good practice.
>

Thanks for the compliment. Your finding it difficult to read once again
makes me long something a little more standard. Learning a new alphabet
is difficult enough. I too find those missing Ts a problem. I pronounce
the T in words like "Saturday" with a T. The dictionary I use drops
them. I think most people would be more comfortable with these Ts in
place. Let me know of any other spellings you find strange. It helps me
out greatly.

Paul
